column1: CARDIOVASCULAR/CIRCULATORY SYSTEM (INCLUDING OPERATIVE)
column2: Which of the following signs and symptoms would you monitor a patient for who has a decreased cardiac output?
column3: Urine output of 360 mL over last 12 hours.
column4: A clubbing appearance to upper extremities.
column5: A decreased sensation of tactile stimulation.
column6: A decrease in bilateral peripheral pulses.
column9: Rationale: Circulatory system involves the assessment of peripheral pulses which would relate to the cardiac output. Urine output of 30 mL/hr is normal
column10: clubbing appearance involves the respiratory system
column11: and tactile stimulation involves the nervous system.

column1: 2. When teaching an older adult patient about coronary artery disease you should include which of the following instructions.
column2: A.Chest pain is the most common symptom experienced.
column3: B.You may have fewer side effects from the use of oral beta blockers.
column4: C. When performing exercise you will need to plan longer warm up time.
column5: D.Dysrhythmias are an abnormal symptom for your age.
column8: Rationale: This age group needs to allow for the steady increase and decrease in their heart rate pre and post exercise. Chest pain is not the most common symptom; they may have unexplained dyspnea
column9: confusion or GI symptoms. This age group may have greater side effects with the use of beta blockers
column10: dysrhythmias are normal for this age group.

column1: 3.A patient with atherosclerosis asks a nurse which factors are responsible for this condition. What is the nurse’s best response?
column2: A.“Injury to the arteries causes them to spasm
column3: reducing blood flow to the extremities.”
column4: B.“Excess fats in your diet are stored in the lining of your arteries
column6: C.“A combination of platelets and fats accumulate
column7: narrowing the artery and reducing blood flow.”
column8: D.“Excess sodium from hypertension causes direct injury to the arteries
column9: reducing blood flow and eventually causing obstruction.”
column12: Rationale: Most researchers believe that a combination of platelet and lipid accumulation following intimal injury is responsible for the process of atherosclerosis.

column1: 4.What specific instructions should the nurse provide to the patient with atherosclerosis who is attempting to stop cigarette smoking with the use of a nicotine patch?
column2: A.“Abruptly discontinuing this patch can cause high blood pressure.”
column3: B.“Abruptly discontinuing this patch can cause nausea and vomiting.”
column4: C.“Smoking while using this patch increases the risk of respiratory infections.”
column5: D. “Smoking while using this patch increases the risk of a heart attack.”
column10: and increases afterload. Smoking while using a nicotine patch increases afterload to such an extent that the myocardium must work harder
column11: with coronary arteries constricted. This may cause a myocardial infarction.

column1: 5.The nurse correlates which pathophysiologic processes with the development of coronary artery disease (CAD)?
column2: A. Atherosclerotic plaques cause spasm and subsequent narrowing of the coronary vessels.
column3: B.Coronary vessels becomes inflamed and injured as a result of excess cholesterol and
column5: C.Macrophages and T cells form a connective tissue matrix in the vessel intima where
column7: D.Atherosclerosis causes coronary vessels to become stiff
column12: Rationale: Atherosclerosis leading to CAD is the result of three processes: (1) the overgrowth of intimal
column13: smooth muscle cells with macrophages and T cells; (2) the formation of a connective tissue in the vessel
column14: intima; and (3) the accumulation of lipids
column15: which serve to narrow the vessel lumen.

column1: 6. A patient is admitted with early-stage heart failure. Which assessment finding does the nurse expect?
column2: A.A drop in blood pressure and urine output.
column3: B. An increase in creatinine and lower extremity edema.
column4: C.An increase in heart rate and respiratory rate.
column9: stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system represents the most immediate response. Adrenergic receptor stimulation causes an increase in heart rate and respiratory rate. The blood pressure will remain the same or elevate slightly.

column1: 7.Which patient statement alerts the nurse to possible heart failure?
column2: A.“I’m drinking more water than usual.”
column3: B. “I’ve been awakened by the need to urinate at night.”
column4: C.“I have to stop halfway up the stairs to catch my breath.”
column5: D.“I have experienced blurred vision on several occasions.”
column8: Rationale: Patients with left-sided heart failure report weakness or fatigue while performing normal activities of daily living as well as difficulty breathing
column9: or “catching their breath.” This occurs as fluid moves into the alveoli.

column1: 9.What physiological response is most likely to occur following surgery?
column2: A.Increase in oxygen use.
column8: Rationale: The need for oxygen is a physiological response to surgery. The immune system has a decreased response
column9: blood sugar levels increase due to a drop in insulin
column10: and coagulation increases as blood becomes more viscous.

column1: 10.The nurse is speaking with a patient who is scheduled for surgery. The patient has expressed concern that they might receive blood products
column2: an act prohibited by their religion. Which of the following is the nurse’s best response?
column3: A.“There are ways to replace blood loss besides blood products.”
column4: B.“Your chance of needing a blood transfusion is small.”
column5: C.“You need to do what is necessary to save your life.”
column6: D.“You could have family members donate blood for you.”
column9: Rationale: There are many ways to replace blood loss such as “bloodless surgery” and minimally invasive surgery
column10: the use of various techniques are also used to reduce the need for transfusion. The patient could also use Epogen or Procrit to increase the red blood cell production. Newer equipment and surgical techniques can allow surgeons to recycle the patients’ blood during surgery.

column1: 11.The nurse is obtaining a patient’s history prior to an elective surgery and the patient states the
column2: following facts. Which fact should be reported to the surgeon and may result in the cancellation of the surgery?
column3: A.“I delivered a baby eight weeks ago and I still have some vaginal discharge.”
column4: B.“I have been taking my oral contraceptives for the last two weeks.”
column5: C. “I have three large boils (furuncles) on the skin of my left shoulder.”
column13: Rationale: A boil or furuncle is a deep skin infection. The most common organism in a boil is Staphylococcus aureus. The presence of this infection places the patient at risk for a wound infection
column14: even when the boil is not located near the planned surgical site. The infection should be treated and cleared before surgery. Because this surgery is elective rather than urgent or emergent
column15: it can be delayed without harming the patient.

column1: 12.The nurse is caring for a postoperative client in the recovery room. Initial assessment shows that the patient is restless
column2: has a thready pulse of 122
column4: and a blood pressure of 116/74. What should the nurse do next?
column5: A.Increase the fluid volume by increasing the IV rate.
column6: B.Inspect the nasal passage for possible obstruction.
column7: C.Check the dressing for the possibility of hemorrhage.
column8: D.Administer additional pain medication as ordered.
column11: Rationale: Restlessness and noisy respirations are usual signs of obstruction and poor circulation.

column1: 13.The health care provider has ordered a one-day postoperative client to ambulate four times per day. What is the best nursing action to take when the client becomes dizzy while being assisted from the bed for the first time?
column2: A.Assist the client quietly back to bed and reassess.
column3: B.Notify the health care provider that client was dizzy.
column4: C.Suggest the client take three or four deep breaths.
column5: D.Have the client sit in a chair until dizziness subsides.
column7: Rationale: It is not unusual for a client to feel dizzy during initial ambulation after surgery due to postural hypotension.  Sitting in a chair will allow the body to adjust to the change in fluid distribution.

column1: 14. The nurse is assessing a client before surgery and observes dark blue
column2: distended veins on the lower legs and ankles. Postoperatively
column3: the nurse would monitor the client for what development?
column10: Rationale: These signs may indicate poor circulation in the lower extremities that would place the client at a higher risk for developing clot formation following surgery.

column1: 15.The nurse is monitoring a client in hypovolemic shock who has been placed on a dopamine hydrochloride drip. Which of the following parameters should the nurse recognizes as the desired response to this drug?
column2: A.Hypotension.
column8: Rationale: Dopamine increases myocardial oxygen consumption which would increase cardiac output.

column1: 16.The nurse is administering a unit of packed red blood cells and the patient complains of chills
column2: headache and nausea. Which of the following is the nurse’s first nursing action?
column3: A.Continue the infusion and obtain a set of vital signs.
column4: B.Stop the infusion stat and notify the health care provider.
column5: C.Slow the infusion and assess for cessation of symptoms.
column6: D.Stop the infusion and allow the child quiet time to rest.
column11: and nausea may or may not be a reaction. Assessment of the vital signs provides more definitive data to further assess the patient for a transfusion reaction.

column1: 17.The nurse is teaching a patient about the newly prescribed medication
column2: atorvastatin (Lipitor). Which instruction needs to be included in the teaching?
column3: A.“Taking this medication can cause constipation.”
column4: B.“Always take this medication on an empty stomach.”
column5: C.“Report any muscle tenderness to your health care provider.”
column6: D.“You may experience flushing of the skin with this medication.”
column9: Rationale: Statin medications can cause muscle myopathies and should be discontinued if the patient has any muscle cramping.

column1: 18. The nurse hears a swishing sound over the right carotid artery while performing auscultation on a patient with atherosclerosis. Which of the following would be the nurse’s best action?
column2: A.Performing carotid massage.
column4: C.No action is necessary because this is a normal finding.
column5: D.Simultaneously palpating the carotid arteries bilaterally.
column8: Rationale: A swishing sound can be a sign of a bruit forming and is abnormal. This finding could indicate an arterial occlusion.

column1: 19.The nurse on the telemetry unit is assessing blood pressure readings on four patients with cardiac problems. Which blood pressure reading suggests to the nurse that the patient’s mean arterial pressure is abnormal and warrants notifying the physician?
column2: A.94/58 mm Hg.
column8: Rationale: To maintain adequate blood flow through the coronary arteries the mean arterial pressure must be at least 60 mm Hg. A mean arterial pressure between 60 and 70 mm Hg is necessary to maintain perfusion of major body organs
column9: such as the brain and kidneys.

column1: 20.At 0730 hours
column2: a nurse receives a verbal order for a cardiac catheterization to be completed on a patient at 1400 hours. Which action should the nurse initiate first?

column1: A.Start an intravenous infusion of 0.9% NaCl.
column2: B.Ask the patient to sign a consent form.
column3: C.Initiate NPO status for the patient.
column4: D.Teach the patient about the procedure.
column7: Rationale: A cardiac catheterization is an invasive procedure and to avoid aspiration the patient should be NPO 6 to 12 hours prior to the procedure. NPO status would be the first action the nurse would initiate with the signing of the consent form and starting an IV after the cardiologist has seen the patient and orders have been written. The cardiologist would also teach the patient about the procedure.

column1: 21. A patient has received health teaching about lifestyle changes that can help reduce the risk for cardiovascular disease. Which of these statements made by the patient indicates a need for further teaching by the nurse?
column2: A. “I have to watch what I eat so that I can lose some weight.”

column1: B.“I quit smoking last year because I have smoked since I was 12.”
column2: C. “I can’t do anything about my disease risk because it’s in my genes.”
column3: D.“I have to take my blood pressure medication as the doctor wants me to.”
column6: Rationale: Although nothing can be done to modify genetic risks of heart disease
column7: other risk factors can be considerably lowered
column11: and psychological factors. The patient does have to watch his diet to reduce the risk for cardiovascular disease. Obesity and a diet high in sodium
column13: and cholesterol will contribute to heart disease. The patient realizes that smoking is a modifiable risk factor.  The patient understands the importance of taking blood pressure medications as prescribed to maintain lower blood pressure and prevent the complications of hypertension.

column1: 22. A middle-aged patient who has a diagnosis of cardiovascular disease is admitted to the telemetry unit for an abnormal heart rhythm and chest discomfort. What physical assessment findings should the nurse expect for this patient? (Select all that apply.)
column2: A. Headache
column13: Rationale: The most common findings would be palpitations
column15: and fatigue. Depending on the patient’s history
column18: headache could also be present. Diarrhea may possibly be caused by medication
column20: etc. that might lower the potassium
column21: which may lead to headaches and hypercapnia.  Hypercapnia is due to hypokalemia and hypoxemia.

column1: 23.A client’s ECG monitor shows asystole
column2: the patient becomes unresponsive and is not breathing. What is the nurse’s first priority?
column5: C. Ventilate with a breathing mask.
column6: D. Elevate the head of the bed.
column9: Rationale: The initial priorities are ABC (airway

column1: 24.A patient with third-degree heart block is discharged to home with a permanent pacemaker. Which of these statements by the patient indicates a need for further discharge teaching?
column2: A.“I get an ID bracelet and card so everyone will know I have a pacemaker.”
column3: B.“If my pulse is too low
column4: I should set the pacemaker to the same rate.”
column5: C.“I have to stay away from magnetic areas and MRI machines.”
column6: D.“I shouldn’t get too close to any telephones
column10: Rationale:  Discharge instructions for patients with pacemakers include obtaining an ID bracelet and card
column11: keep at least 6 inches away from handheld cellular phones
column12: use ear on opposite side of pacemaker
column13: and avoid strong electromagnetic fields such as MRI machines.
column18: The nurse finds positive rebound tenderness in a client with abdominal pain.
column19: Which of the following actions will the nurse implement?
column20: A.Keep the client NPO in preparation for possible surgery.
column21: B.Document this normal finding in the client’s record.
column22: C.Immediately auscultate the client’s abdomen for bowel sounds.
column23: D.Repeat the maneuver with the client in left Sims position
column27: Rationale: Rebound tenderness could be a sign that something has ruptured and/or bleeding  within the abdomen and will most likely need surgical intervention.

column1: 26.The nurse is caring for a client with malabsorption.  Which of the following laboratory findings might the nurse expect this client to exhibit?
column2: A.Excess bilirubin levels resulting from protein catabolism.
column3: B.Elevated fecal fat level resulting from nonabsorbed fats.
column4: C.Increased hemoglobin level resulting from microcytic anemia.
column5: D.Increased blood glucose levels resulting from hyperinsulinemia.
column8: Rationale: A quantitative fecal fat analysis is elevated in malabsorption due to unabsorbed fat causing steatorrhea or greater than normal amounts of fat in the feces.

column1: 27.Which laboratory finding will the nurse expect to find on assessment of a client with advanced liver disease?
A.Ammonia 120 mg/dL; Serum Albumin 1.9 g/dL.
B.Serum amylase 125 units/L; calcium
column2: 10.5 mg/dL.

column1: C.Hemoglobin
column2: 13.4 g/dL; direct bilirubin

column1: D.Prothrombin time
column2: 17.5 sec; alkaline phosphatase
column7: Rationale: The ammonia level is elevated and the serum albumin level is low both are indicative of advanced liver disease.

column1: The nurse in the emergency room is assessing a client with cirrhosis. The client presents with hematemesis
column2: confusion
column3: a blood pressure of 95/43 and an apical pulse of 115. Which of the following tests should the nurse anticipate the health care provider to order?
column10: Rationale: Endoscopy would be done first to identify the source of the bleeding.  Gastroscopy is too specific and the other tests would not be appropriate for possible esophageal varices.

column1: 29.The nurse is performing discharge teaching for a client with peptic ulcer disease (PUD) who will be taking
column2: pantoprazole (Protonix)
column3: and aluminum hydroxide (Maalox). Which of the following statements by the client indicates understanding of the teaching?
column4: A.“I should not take the Maalox with the other medications.”
column5: B.“The Protonix will kill the E.Coli germ that caused the ulcers.”
column6: C.“Protonix works by coating the lining of my stomach.”
column7: D.“I should decrease the dose of Maalox if the pain is not relieved.”
column10: Rationale: Antacids buffer gastric acid and prevent the formation of pepsin. Maalox when administered alone will increase the GI side effects and when administered in combination can overcome the unpleasant side effects.
column14: A client with a recent diagnosis of early peptic ulcer disease needs health teaching about nutrition therapy. Which of the following foods should the nurse teach the client to avoid? (Select all that apply)
column28: Rationale: Although there is no evidence that dietary restriction reduces gastric acid secretion or promotes tissue healing
column29: a bland diet may assist in relieving symptoms. Patients should be taught to avoid substances that increase gastric acid secretion
column30: such as those listed above. Green beans and scrambled eggs do not stimulate gastric acid secretion because they are bland and nonirritating.
column34: The nurse is caring for a client recently diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease (PUD).  Which of the following assessment findings requires an immediate nursing action?
column35: Client vomits 100 mL of bright red fluid.
column36: Client has blood pressure of 170/70 in left arm.

column1: Client has hemoglobin of 8.8 mg/dL.
column2: Client passes 400 mL of loose green stool.
column5: Rationale: The most common complication of PUD are hemorrhage
column8: and intractable disease. Hemorrhage is the most serious complication.
column12: The nurse is caring for a client who is at risk for developing gastritis. Which finding from the client’s history leads the nurse to this conclusion?
column13: The client is lactose-intolerant and cannot drink milk.
column14: The client recently traveled to Mexico and South America.
column15: The client works at least 60 hours per week in a stressful job.
column16: The client takes naproxen sodium (Naprosyn) 500 mg daily for arthritis pain.
column20: Rationale: Motrin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can cause gastritis
column21: even if symptoms are not yet apparent. Stress
column23: and spicy foods do not increase risk for gastritis.
column27: The nurse is caring for a female client who has just received a prescription for misoprostol (Cytotec). Which instructions will the nurse provide to the client regarding this medication?
column28: “You may dissolve the contents of the capsule in warm water if it is difficult to swallow.”
column29: “Take this medication on an empty stomach just before going to bed every evening.”
column30: “Make sure you use an effective form of birth control when taking this medication.”
column31: “You should add fiber to your diet because this medication may cause constipation.”
column34: Rationale: Cytotec may cause uterine rupture
column36: and fetal deformities when taken during pregnancy. Clients should be careful not to become pregnant while taking the medication. Cytotec may cause diarrhea and should be taken with food.

column1: 33.The nurse is caring for a patient with biliary colic. In managing the pain the client is experiencing
column2: which of the following would the nurse anticipate the health care provider to order?
column12: Rationale: Biliary colic is severe pain caused by spasm of the ducts (usually R/T gallstones).  Acute biliary pain requires opioid analgesia such as morphine or hydromorphone (Dilaudid).  Demerol is thought to increase spasms of the sphincter of Oddi and is no longer used to relieve biliary pain and is thought to break down into a toxic metabolite (normeperidine) and can cause seizures
column13: especially in older adults. Questran is an antilipemic
column17: and K will not relieve pain.
column21: The nurse is caring for a client recovering from a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The client complains to the nurse that “my abdomen is swollen and I am very uncomfortable.”  Which of the following would be the nurse’s best response?
column22: “I will notify your health care provider. The laser can sometimes cause bleeding.”
column23: “What you are feeling is common after the procedure and is nothing to worry about.”
column24: “These symptoms may be related to the CO2 insufflation
column26: “The T-tube may have become lodged against the bile duct wall causing the discomfort.”
column29: Rationale: The only choice that includes assessment is C. Assessment is the first step in responding to the client’s concern.
column33: The nurse is caring for a client one day post-operative who had an incisional cholecystectomy with a T- tube and is now complaining of nausea and abdominal distention. Which of the following interventions should the nurse perform first?
column36: Assess the tubing for potential kinking.
column37: Irrigate the tube with normal saline.
column40: Rationale: One of the priorities for caring for the patient with a T-tube is to assess the drainage system for pulling
column42: or tangling on the right side.  Clamping the tube would not be on the first day post-operative
column43: administering antiemetic medications are not warranted
column44: and you never irrigate a t-tube.

column1: 35.The nurse is caring for a client with abdominal pain. The client complains of abdominal pain with visible peristaltic waves
column2: nausea
column3: and vomiting with abdominal distention noted.  Which of the following conditions does the nurse suspect?
column10: Rationale: Abdominal pain with peristaltic waves
column12: and vomiting with abdominal distention are key features to a small bowel obstruction.

column1: 36. The nurse is caring for a postoperative client who complains of pain in the shoulder blades following laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery. Which direction will the nurse give to the nursing assistant to help relieve the client’s pain?
column2: A.“Ambulate the client in the hallway as often as tolerated.”
column3: B.“Apply a cold compress to the client’s back as needed.”
column4: C.“Encourage the client to take sips of hot tea or broth.”
column5: D.“Remind the client to cough and deep breathe every hour.”
column8: Rationale: Encourage early ambulation to promote absorption of the carbon dioxide. None of the remaining interventions will relieve the pain.

column1: 37.The nurse is caring for an 18-year old admitted with acute appendicitis exhibiting right lower quadrant pain. Which of the following indicators should the nurse assess the client for to determine if the pain is secondary to appendicitis?
column2: A.Gastric hyperacidity.
column8: Rationale: Rebound tenderness is the most common cause appendicitis. Hyperacidity would cause epigastric pain
column9: urinary retention does not cause lower right quadrant pain
column10: and there is generally decreased bowel motility distal to an inflamed appendix.

column1: 38. The nurse is caring for a client who is postoperative for a perforated appendix and has localized peritonitis. Which of the following positions should the nurse place this client?
column2: A.Sims’ position.
column8: Rationale: Semi-fowler’s position aids in drainage and prevents the spread of infection throughout the abdominal cavity. This position allows for any of the local drainage to remain in the lower abdomen.

column1: 39. The nurse is caring for a client with Crohn’s disease who has undergone a barium enema that identified the presence of strictures in the ileum. Which of the following findings should the nurse monitor closely for?
column2: A.Peritonitis.
column8: Rationale: Bowel strictures are a common complication of Crohn’s disease and can result in an acute bowel obstruction.

column1: 40. The nurse is caring for a client admitted with acute diverticulitis. Which of the following should the nurse anticipate the health care provider to include in the treatment plan? (Select all that apply)
column2: A.Nothing by mouth.
column10: Rationale: The goal for diverticulitis is to promote bowel rest. Decreasing oral intake will allow for bowel resting. Antibiotics are part of the routine treatment regimen. Ambulation will not allow for bowel rest
column11: nausea is not a concern with diverticulitis
column12: and there is no need for deep breathing exercises.

column1: 41. The nurse is teaching a client who has been diagnosed with diverticulosis. Which instruction should the nurse include in the teaching session?
column2: A.Discuss the importance of drinking 1
column4: B.Instruct the client to exercise at least three (3) times a week.
column5: C.Teach the client about a eating a low-residue diet.
column6: D.Explain the need to have daily bowel movements.
column10: which is a potentially life-threatening complication of diverticulosis.

column1: 42. The nurse is discussion the therapeutic diet with a client diagnosed with diverticulosis. Which of the following meals indicates that the client understands the discharge teaching?
column2: A.Fried fish
column8: C.Chicken salad on whole-wheat bread and water.
column14: Rationale: Chicken salad and whole-wheat bread are high in fiber
column15: which is the therapeutic diet prescribed for clients with diverticulosis. An adequate intake of water helps prevent constipation.

column1: 43.The nurse is reviewing laboratory results of a client who has been diagnosed with Crohn’s disease. Which of the following results will the nurse report to the health care provider as soon as possible?
column2: A. White blood cell count of 8
column4: B. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 15 mm in 1 hour.

column1: C.Red blood cell count of 2.9 million/cu mm.
column2: D. Blood urea nitrogen of 18 mg/dL.

column1: Rationale: Red blood cell count of 2.9 million/cu mm is low and will impact the delivery of sufficient oxygen to the tissues. The remaining labs are within the normal limits.
column2: Physiological adaptation

column1: 44.The nurse is caring for a 24-year old male client with acute pancreatitis. Which of the following room assignments is optimal?
column2: A.A semi-private room with a 63-year old male who has a fracture and is in traction.
column3: B.A private room at the far end of the unit away from the nurses’ station.
column4: C.A secluded room in close proximity to the nurses’ station.
column5: D.A semi-private room with 46-year old male with pancreatic cancer.
column8: Rationale: The main focus for clients with acute pancreatitis is to control the pain and provide interventions that decrease GI tract activity
column9: thus decreasing pancreatic stimulation. The client needs to be fasting and even smelling foods can cause enzyme production and increase pain related to pancreatic inflammation.

column1: 45. The nurse is caring for a client with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).  Which of the following H2 receptor blocker medications might the nurse expect the healthcare provider to prescribe?
column2: A. Zantac.
column8: Rationale: Zantac is the a H2 receptor blocker and decreases acid production. Protonix and Prilosec are proton pump inhibitors and Flagyl is an antifungal medication.

column1: 46. The nurse is assessing a client with a duodenal ulcer. Which of the following descriptors might the nurse expect the client to use when describing their pain?
column2: A."A constant
column3: dull ache in the abdominal area.”
column6: C.“Pain that awakens me up while sleeping at night.”
column7: D.“Shoulder pain that occurs after I eat fried foods.”
column10: Rationale: The pain for a duodenal ulcer is sudden
column11: sharp and occurs 90-180 minutes after a meal
column12: and often awakens the patient between 1 and 2 am.

column1: 47.The nurse is caring for a client with a history of Laennec’s cirrhosis. Which of the following does the nurse correlate with the history?
column2: A. Gallstones.
column10: is caused by the toxic effect of alcohol on the liver. The nurse should ask the client about a history of alcohol use.

column1: 48. The nurse is caring for a 22-year old client who is diagnosed as having acute viral hepatitis A. Which of the following interventions is important in facilitating the regeneration of hepatic cells?A.Scheduling uninterrupted rest periods during the day.
column2: B.Promoting a high fat
column5: C.Encouraging an active exercise program at least four times per day.
column6: D.Maintaining daily administration of interferon alpha per orders.
column9: Rationale: Rest periods are an essential intervention to reduce the liver’s metabolic demands and increase its blood supply. Diet would be high caloric with moderate amounts of fats and proteins. Interferon alpha is administered to reduce the replication of the hepatitis B virus.

column1: 49.The nurse is caring for a client who has been newly diagnosed with hepatitis. The health care provider has determined that the client has contracted the infection from contaminated food. Which of the following type of hepatitis is the client experiencing?
column2: A.Hepatitis A.
column8: Rationale: Hepatitis A is transmitted by the fecal-oral route via contaminated food or infected food handlers. Hepatitis B
column10: and D are transmitted most commonly via infected blood or body fluids.

column1: 50. The nurse is caring for a client who has developed hepatitis A after eating contaminated oysters. Which of the following would the nurse assess for in the client?
column2: A.Malaise.
column8: Rationale: Hepatitis causes gastrointestinal symptoms such as anorexia
column11: and weight loss. Fatigue and malaise are common. Stools will be light or clay-colored if conjugated bilirubin is unable to flow out of the liver because of inflammation or obstruction of the bile ducts.

column1: 51.The nurse is caring for a client who is admitted to the hospital with viral hepatitis
column2: complaining of having no appetite and losing the taste for food. Which of the following instructions should the nurse provide the client to promote adequate nutrition?
column3: A.Select your foods which are higher in fat content.
column4: B.Increase your intake of fluids including fruit juices.
column5: C.Eat a good supper when anorexia is not as severe.
column7: preferably only three large meals per day.
column10: Rationale: Although no special diet is required to treat viral hepatitis
column11: it is generally recommended that clients consume a low-fat diet. Small frequent meals are preferable and may even prevent nausea. Frequently
column12: appetite is better in the morning
column13: so it is easier to eat a good breakfast. An adequate fluid intake of 2500-3000 mL/day that includes nutritional juices is also important.
